title: What Does “TS” Mean? (Plus, When & How to Use It)

steps.title: The abbreviation “TS” stands for “talk soon.”
steps.content: The abbreviation “TS” stands for “talk soon.” Over text, “TS” is the shortened version of the phrase “talk soon.” [1] X Research source It’s a quick way to end a conversation and tell the other person that you plan to speak with them in the near future. Since it’s a texting abbreviation, save it for casual exchanges online with close loved ones. Them: “I really enjoy our conversations.” You: “Same! It was so great to catch up with you, but I have to run an errand. TS ❤️”

steps.title: “TS” is also short for “tough s***.”
steps.content: “TS” is also short for “tough s***.” Sometimes, “TS” is used to express indifference or dismissal toward another person’s problem. If someone opens up about a tough situation, for example, “TS” is an unsympathetic response to brush them off and say “that’s too bad for you.” [2] X Research source Avoid using the term if you know someone who is struggling, and show support by actively listening to them. Them: “I can’t believe I failed my exam!” You: “TS, you should have studied instead of going to the party on Thursday 💀”

steps.title: Use “TS” (“talk soon”) to wrap up a conversation over text.
steps.content: Use “TS” (“talk soon”) to wrap up a conversation over text. If you need to leave the chat, text “TS” (“talk soon”) to end the conversation on a positive note. It’s a casual and friendly sign-off that indicates you have to postpone a discussion for a later time. Them: “Thanks for letting me rant 💗” You: “OMG, of course! I do have to head to an appointment but TS 🫰” Them: “I can’t believe they broke up!” You: “I know, it’s so crazy 🤯 I’m starting work but we’ll TS…I want to hear all the details!”

steps.title: Send “TS” (“talk soon”) to confirm plans with someone.
steps.content: Send “TS” (“talk soon”) to confirm plans with someone. If you’ve discussed future plans with the other person, use “TS” (“talk soon”) as a polite parting phrase. It confirms the details of your future exchange and communicates that you’re excited to see or meet them soon. Them: “Are you free to FaceTime on Saturday?” You: “Yes! TS 🥰” Them: “I’m so excited for our picnic this weekend!” You: “Me too 🤩 I have to head to work, but let’s discuss the details tomorrow! TS ✨”

steps.title: Text “TS” (“tough s***”) to dismiss someone’s problem.
steps.content: Text “TS” (“tough s***”) to dismiss someone’s problem. If your friend or family member shares a negative experience that isn’t super important, send “TS” (“tough s***”) to acknowledge what they’ve said. It’s a casual way to lighten the mood and poke fun at them in a loving way. With that being said, use your best judgment when it comes to texting this slang term—you don’t want to anger or offend the other person if they’re going through something serious. [3] X Research source Them: “Dude, I can’t believe I tripped in front of her!” You: “TS, you should’ve tied your shoes 🤣” Them: “I need a ride because my friend bailed on me.” You: “TS, I’m going to the mall.” Them: “Seriously???” You: “Nah, I’m just messing with you 💀 I’m OTW!”

steps.title: That s***
steps.content: That s*** On social media, “TS” may also stand for “that s***.” It’s a casual way to emphasize the importance of something, such as a specific subject, event, or object. For example, someone might say, “did you watch TS last night?” when referring to a TV show. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Top secret
steps.content: Top secret In government, “TS” is short for “top secret,” which refers to the highest level of security clearance for most government employees. It gives them access to sensitive information that isn’t available to the public, and it takes 6-8 months to go through the clearance process. [5] X Research source

steps.title: True story
steps.content: True story In texting and on social media, the slang term “true story” is a common way to affirm someone’s story or statement. It means something actually happened and the other person is being truthful. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Technical specification
steps.content: Technical specification This is a document that outlines a software development project’s requirements, goals, and constraints. It’s essentially a detailed plan that describes how to build and design a solution for a technical problem. [7] X Research source

steps.title: TypeScript
steps.content: TypeScript This is a free and popular programming language developed by Microsoft. It adds static typing to JavaScript, allowing people to be more specific about the data being passed around within their code. [8] X Research source

steps.title: TeamSpeak
steps.content: TeamSpeak In the gaming world, the term “TS” stands for “TeamSpeak.” It’s a proprietary voice chat software for audio communication between users, similar to a telephone conference call. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Telesync
steps.content: Telesync In film, “TS” stands for “telesync,” which is a bootleg recording of a film in a movie theater. Since the video and audio is sourced externally, the film is much lower in quality compared to official releases. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Test suite
steps.content: Test suite In software development, the term “TS” is short for “test suite.” It refers to a collection of test cases that are meant to evaluate the performance and functionality of a specific program. [11] X Trustworthy Source U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission Independent U.S. government agency responsible for regulating the securities industry, which includes stocks and options exchanges Go to source

steps.title: Tourette syndrome
steps.content: Tourette syndrome Occasionally, “TS” stands for “tourette syndrome,” which is a nervous system disorder that involves repetitive movements or unwanted sounds (called tics). Symptoms vary from person to person, but they may include repeatedly blinking, shrugging, or grunting. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Transsexual
steps.content: Transsexual Sometimes, the term “TS” is short for “transsexual.” This describes a person who has a different gender identity to their sex assigned at birth. They may physically transition from one gender to another, through changes like taking hormones or undergoing surgery. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Turboshaft
steps.content: Turboshaft In aviation, “TS” stands for “turboshaft,” which is a type of jet engine that operates without any major moving parts. It produces shaft power to drive machinery, instead of producing thrust, and it’s most commonly used in helicopters and auxiliary power units. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Tensile strength
steps.content: Tensile strength In science, the “TS” may stand for “tensile strength,” or the maximum stress that a material can withstand before breaking while being stretched or pulled. It’s a key parameter in borehole fracture calculations. [15] X Trustworthy Source Science Direct Online archive of peer-reviewed research on scientific, technical and medical topics Go to source

steps.title: Tennessine
steps.content: Tennessine In chemistry, “TS” represents the element tennessine. It has an atomic number of 117, and is classified as a halogen on the periodic table. [16] X Research source

steps.title: “TTYL”
steps.content: “TTYL” Often used over text, “TTYL” stands for “talk to you later. Send it to a friend, family member, or romantic partner to quickly end the conversation, plus express your plans to catch up soon.” [17] X Research source “I have to get back to work, TTYL!” “About to walk into my job interview…TTYL!” “Ahhh, I forgot I had to pick up my dad from work. TTYL!”

steps.title: “ML”
steps.content: “ML” If you’re texting a loved one, use “ML” as a warm and affectionate sign off. It stands for “much love,” which implies you’re sending them your love and support. Think of it as a sweeter way of saying “take care” or “best wishes!” [18] X Research source “I have to go, but it was so great to catch up! ML 💘” “I’m so glad we reconnected, and I hope things work out for you. ML 🫂” “Thanks for listening to me 🥹 I have to pick up someone, but we’ll talk soon! ML 🫶”

steps.title: “IDGAF”
steps.content: “IDGAF” If you don’t care about a certain situation or idea, respond with “IDGAF.” It stands for “I don’t give a f***,” and it’s a popular way to dismiss something. Depending on your tone and topic of the conversation, it can come off as funny, relatable, or savage. [19] X Research source “IDGAF about the conference on Thursday.” “Not gonna lie…IDGAF about the midterm 😂” “Can you stop bringing up past drama? IDGAF!”

steps.title: “IDC”
steps.content: “IDC” This popular slang expression stands for “I don’t care.” It’s not as rude or aggressive as “tough s***” or “IDGAF,” making it a great option when you want to express indifference toward a person, event, or idea. [20] X Research source “IDC what we eat for dinner.” “IDC about work drama because I’m going on vacation next week 😅” “IDC about her relationship because it literally has no impact on my life…”
